bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, April 30, 1940

div1.p: Hench thanks Rodriguez Leon for her photographs of Camp Lazear. He regrets the lack of recognition extended to her father for his yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, April 30, 1940
div1.opener:
yellow fever
April 30, 1940
Senora Estella Agramonte Rodreguez-Leon
311 Calle 15 entre H et I
Havana, Cuba
My dear Senora Rodreguez-Leon:
div1.p:
Permit me to send you a few photographs which I took in Havana, and allow
me to thank you again for your great kindness to Mrs. Hench and to me.

I found a great amount of work waiting for me on my return and almost at
once we had a medical convention here which necessitated my having a house guest.
On top of that, our nine-year old boy developed acute appendicitis and had to be
operated on, but is now recovering nicely.

I am having our photographic department try to copy the rather faded photo-
graphs of Camp Lazear. I sincerely hope that we can get some good ones out of them,
and I most assuredly appreciate your kindness in lending them to me. I will mail
them shortly, by registered post.

I sincerely hope that you got the original carbon copy of the letter your
father wrote to Dr. Hemmeter. I sent you also another copy that you might use for
some other annoying inquiring reporter like myself. I have been able to find one of
the interesting articles referred to in your father's letter to Dr. Hemmeter but not
the other, and if I cannot borrow them from some library here, I would most assuredly
be grateful if you would lend them to me, sending them by registered mail, but please
do not bother about this as yet. I will try in another American library first. The
one I cannot seem to get is the George Washington University publication, Medical
Science Series, the article by H. H. Donnally.

I only wish indeed that I had been able to meet you earlier and had more time
to go over your extremely interesting and valuable data. I should like, without bother-
ing you further, to write up the story as best I can, and will send you a copy of it after
some weeks. I am going to try to give due credit to everyone. I do think your father
was slighted by the officials in Washington when the work was first published. Fortun-
ately, the Surgeon General's office made a correction and in later publications, your
father receives much more credit, although perhaps not nearly as much as he deserved.
You have no idea how desirous I am to be permitted to see some of the old photographs
which your father took or may have had taken of his colleagues on the Yellow Fever
Commission, and perhaps of Camp Lazear. I have been unable to find any photographs as
yet of Military Hospital No. 1, where your father worked. I am trying to find a photo-
graph in the Army Museum, and perhaps, if it is not too much trouble, you may, some time
soon, be able to find the photographs. I realize what an imposition this is to ask you
to open up old trunks and boxes, but I am sure that you know I am only doing this in
behalf of the honored memory of those who did such a wonderful piece of work. I left
a small sum of money with Mr. Moran to cover certain incidental expenses for little
- 2 -
projects which I have asked him to carry out for me, and perhaps you will not think
me presumptuous in suggesting that it might be easier for you to hire some husky
handy man or drayman, whom you could take to the house where the boxes are, and have
him push them around and open them up under your supervision. If you should care to
do this, and thus save yourself the physical labor of doing this annoying job yourself,
I shall be only too delighted if you will permit me to pay the expenses of this man.
I sincerely hope that you will not think me forward in offering this. I only do so
to show you how anxious I am to have your further help and to show you, in any case,
how grateful I am for what you have already done for me.

Please give your husband our very best wishes. We recall with much interest
the stories of the exciting adventures which he had in the Hotel Nacionale. I can
assure you that they were much more exciting than our adventures in the same hotel:
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
